Exercises

Write complete paradigms of the following nouns: ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç, ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§ß, ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç, ‡§ß‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞

Translate the following passages into English and rewrite them with all known sandhis;

‡•ß. ‡§è‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§ï‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É

‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ã‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§§‡•Å ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø - ‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§ß‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§, ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å ‡•´ …. ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É (Alexander) ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç, ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡§™‡§É ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§É ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏(Greece)‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ê‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç - ‡§π‡•á ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É

161

‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø (sets), ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç (destroy) ‡§® ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§É ‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡§Æ‡§É ‡§®‡•à‡§µ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§µ‡§¶, ‡§ï‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü? ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ? ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§

‡§ö‡•§ ‡•™. ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É, ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§è‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§® ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ü ‡•§ ‡•´. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§® ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø,

‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§® ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§è‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§É ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø - ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§É ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§µ‡•á‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø

‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§è‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§π‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•¨. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡•§

‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§â‡§∑‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ö ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§É ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ú‡§É ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§ö ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ß‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§™‡§¶‡§É ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§É ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§É (illness) ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•à‡§É ‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§∑‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§â‡§∞‡§É ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç (broken), ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø

‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§ß‡§®‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§∑‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¶. ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§É ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§â‡§∑‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§§‡§ø? ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§É ‡§ö‡•á‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø

‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ

‡§∏‡§π‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß. ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∑‡§ú‡§É ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§ö ‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§É ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É‡•§ ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É

‡§Ø‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§É ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á, ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§É ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É? ‡•ß‡•®. ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§É ‡§µ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É

‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á - ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á , ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§è‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§§‡§™‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§É ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§è‡§§‡•á ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§è‡§ï

162‡§è‡§µ ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡•á‡§ß‡§∏‡§É ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§ö ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á

‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©. ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§ã‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§π‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§ö

‡§π‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§§‡•Å ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§É ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§π‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∑‡§ø ‡§≤‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á? ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§É ‡§π‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∑‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§É (smoke) ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡§≤‡§É ‡§ã‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§π‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∑‡§ø

‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•™. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§¶‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç - ‡§π‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ, ‡§è‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡§ø

‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§§‡§µ ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡§É ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡§æ ‡§è‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§§‡•á (shines) ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§§‡§É ‡§è‡§µ ‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§É ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§® ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§è‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§É ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡•Ä‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§É ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§É ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç - ‡§π‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§É, ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

Translate the following into Sanskrit:

‡§≤‡§∏

The mendicants will go to the forests and will recite the hymns. Do the merchants, doctors, and priests like flowers? When the moon shines in the sky, we are all happy. Without the moon, there is darkness in the world, Similarly, without a poet’s poem, there is darkness in the heart. When the king entered the forest with his arrows, the animals ran in all directions. When the mendicants come, the priests leave.

The priests stand at the gate of the palace and praise the king.

A king is the lord (‡§™‡§§‡§ø) of the people (‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç). The mind of a good-hearted man is happy when he sees the beauty of the world.

163

The king’s fame spreads all over the world. It also reaches the sky. For that reason, the moon looks white.

Write any five Sanskrit sentences of your own.

164

20

Consonant-final nouns (continued) Present active participles for active (‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§™‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç) verbs

Active verbs form their present active participles with the affix 3cm A simple way of forming the present active participle stem is to replace the affix ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø (or ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø for the 3rd conjugation) in the present 3rd pl. by the affix ‡§Ö‡§§ . Examples:

“(He who is) going” ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç - ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø “(He who is) playing” ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç - ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø “(He who is) striking” ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§§‡•ç - ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‚Äú(He who is) stealing" ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç - ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø

For a full listing of the present participles, see the list in Lesson 35. Participles like ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‚Äúgoing" structurally behave like adjectives of the agents they qualify, and hence, like other adjectives, they follow the case, gender and number of the substantive (i.e. the agent-word). In masculine and neuter, the stem remains ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•Å, but in feminine the stem becomes ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä with the addition of the feminine affix i, and it follows the standard paradigm of ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä.

Within the masculine and neuter paradigms, we find an alter nation between the strong stem (gacchant-) and the weak stem (gacchat-). The strong stem forms are italicized in the paradigms.

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§

m.

“(He who is) going”

Nom Acc Inst

Dat

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç

D ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É

Abl

Gen Loc Voc

165

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç n. “(That which is going”

Nom Acc Voc

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø

The rest of the paradigm is like the masculine paradigm.

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä

f. “(She who is) going”

Nom

Acc

Inst Dat Abl

Gen Loc Voc

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã

‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É

The present active participles from the active verbs of the sixth conjugation have the following optional forms:

Neuter Nom., Acc., Voc., dual: ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§§‡•Ä or ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä Feminine stem: ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§§‡•Ä- or ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä

Use of the active present participles for active (

  1. verbs:

According to Sanskrit grammarians, these participles cannot be used to simply replace a present tense verb form. For instance, a simple sentence like ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‚ÄúRama is going" cannot be replaced with: *‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç or *‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

166

Present participles, both active as well as middle, express progressive aspect. In general, the present participle takes on the same tense as the main verb, rather than a fixed present tense. This relationship can be seen by examining the approxi mately corresponding relative-clause phrases.

Main Cl Verb PRESENT tense

a) ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§

“I see the man going along the road.” b) ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§

“I see the man who goes (is going) along the road.”

Observe the following transformations:

Saw

man

1a ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‚ÄúI saw the wife of

the man who went by the road." 1b ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§É ‡§®‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‚ÄúI saw the wife of the man

(the man) going by the road." 2a ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ “The man who is going by

the road, he sees my wife.” ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúThe man going by the road

sees my wife." 3a ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI give wealth to the man

who is going by the road." ___ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI give wealth to the man going

by the road." 4a ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI see those women who

are falling on the ground." 4b ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI see the women falling on the

ground." 5a ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúThose women who fall

on the ground curse God." ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúThe women falling on the ground curse God."

omen

167

Future active participles for active (Re

) verbs

These are formed on similar lines. By using the 3rd sg. active future forms like thoug, one can formulate the future active participle stems like - “(He who) will be going” or “(He who) is going to go”. The paradigms of these future active participles are identical with those of the present active participles. The sixth conjugation active verbs have the same alternations (i.e. 31 vs 3 ) in future active participles. Examples:

1101

1a ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI see the man who will go

to the village." 1b ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI see the man who is going to go

to the village." 2a Tare Th Tua opet 3EH 974 423 I ‚ÄúI give money to

that woman who will go to the village." 2b ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI give money to the woman

who will go to the village." 3a ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§® ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI do not want that wealth

which will perish." 3b ‡§®‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§® ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI do not want the perishable

wealth."

Exercises

Write the complete paradigms of the following participles: 1) da 2) ICE 3) atit 4) Ufod 5) foota 6) pa

168

Translate the following sentences into English, and convert the present and future active participle constructions into yad-tad constructions:

‡•ß. ‡§ú‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§§‡•å ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•®. ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•©. ‡§™‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•å ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•™. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•´. ‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•¨. ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•≠. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§É ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§É ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•Ø. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø - ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§É ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¶. ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ó‡§£‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•®. ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©. ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•Å‡§∑‡§£‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•™. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•´. ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¨. ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡§†‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•≠. ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§® ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•Æ. ‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Ω‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•Ø. ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡•á ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§•‡§É ‡•§ ‡•®‡•¶. ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§É ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡§Ö‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•®‡•ß. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§É ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§É ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•®‡•®. ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•®‡•©. ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•®‡•™. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•®‡•´. ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•®‡•¨. ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•á‡§™‡§§ ‡•§ ‡•®‡•≠. ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•®‡•Æ. ‡§π‡•á ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤, ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§® ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•®‡•ß. ‡§π‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§® ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•©‡•¶. ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç - ‡§π‡•á ‡§®‡•É‡§™, ‡§® 169

‡•©‡•ß. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•©‡•®. ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•©‡•©. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§π‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ 28. #2: tract: yo il ‡•©‡•´. ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§ß‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡•§ ‡•©‡•¨. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§

Convert sentences in Lesson 12, Exercises 1 & 2 to present participle constructions. (You may need to adjust the meaning a little bit.)

following

into

Sanskrit

using

present

Translate the participles:

mi aj swoo

Wishing to obtain wealth, the priests recite the hymns.

I see the king looking at the flowers.

The poet praised the hero conquering the enemies. 4. Sitting on the trees, the birds eat fruits.

The mendicants see the servants carrying the burden. I spoke to the man who was going to go to the village. Thinking of God’s power, the sages worship him. The father gave fruits to the son sitting near the lake, Watching the beauty of the garden, she stood at the

door. 10. The mind of a person thinking only of money has no

peace (UIA f). 11. Falling on the ground, I said to my teacher: “Why do

you not like me?” 12. I saw the man stealing my horse. 13. Knowing the truth, you sat under a tree in the forest. 14. Saluting the teacher, the woman sat in front of him. 15. Throwing the gold into the river, the sage looked at the

king.

Write any five Sanskrit sentences of your own.

170

21

Present agentive cadit participles for middle (HC-9SD) verbs

In meaning these participles are exactly like the present active voice participles for active verbs (497) and they follow the same syntactic rules.

Their structure, however, is somewhat different, but simpler than the present active participles for active (H ) verbs. For middle (311C

verbs in the conjugations 1, 4, 6 and 10, these present active voice participles are formed by adding the affix mƒÅna to the verbal base. (For participles with the affix -√§na for other conjugations, see Lesson 35). The verbal base is obtained by simply removing the affix-te in the 3rd sing. present forms. Examples:

(He who) speaks or is speaking HT414

Hera (He who) exists

‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á (He who) requests

‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®

‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡§§‡•á

The present active voice participles for middle verbs, such as HNM-, are declined in masculine and neuter like the masculine and neuter nouns in a. In feminine, a feminine marker affix ƒÅ is added to the basic stem and we get the feminine stems like 41941. This is declined simply like any feminine noun in long ƒÅ.

Note that the constructions are only approximately similar to the present participle constructions, and that the 46

constructions do not express the notion of progressive aspect expressed by the present participle constructions. Examples:

la RA HT JE fa√ßa ar 364 A-GIGI ‚ÄúI curse the woman

who argues with me." 1b ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI curse the woman

arguing with me." 2a 4: #9: 72114 ed ey yar 474 YESI I ‚ÄúI give wealth to the

son of the sage who is plunging in the river."

171

2b ETH 6-HRT **: TEIR HLUTI “I give wealth to the

son of the sage plunging in the river.” 3a ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡•á ‡•§ ‚ÄúI plunge in the river which

is in the forest." 3b ‡§¨‡§®‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡•á ‡•§ ‚ÄúI plunge in the river which is

in the forest." Present passive (HD) participles

These are formed by adding the affix -mƒÅna to the passive verbal base. The passive verbal base can be obtained by removing the affix -te in a passive present 3rd sing. form, e.g. STRICT >

TRT4R-. Examples:

“That which is being given” ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®- ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‚ÄúThat which is being gone to" TRF- ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á “That which is being taken” ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®- ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á “That which is being eaten”

‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®- ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á “That which is being hit”

GER

‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á In masculine and neuter, the present passive participles are declined like masculine and neuter nouns in a. In feminine, a feminine marker affix ƒÅ is added to the basic stem, and then the feminine stem is declined like a feminine noun in long a.

Examples: 1a ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§® ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§§‡•á ‡•§ “The village which is visited

(lit. gone to) by RƒÅma does not appeal to me.” 1b ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§® ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‚ÄúThe village being visited by

RƒÅma does not appeal to me." 2a ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡•§ ‚ÄúThe woman who is being seen

by you is your sister." 2b ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡•§ ‚ÄúThe woman being seen by you is

your sister." 3a ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡•á ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúThe wealth which is being

stolen by the servant falls into the well." 3b ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§® ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡•á ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúThe money being stolen by the

servant falls into the well."

172J

4a ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§†‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§® ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI will not

give you the books which are being read by me." 4b ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§†‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§® ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI will not give you

the books being read by me."

Vocabulary

‚Ä¢ ‡§™‡§æ‡§™ n. sin - ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ f. girl

‚Ä¢ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞ m. monkey

‚Ä¢ ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä f. female crocodile - ‡§§‡§æ‡§á, ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø 10P. to beat

‚Ä¢ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞

¬∑ ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø

sweet heart crocodile sweet

‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞

‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å

a.

Exercises

Write down twenty present active voice participles for middle verbs and their masculine and feminine genitive forms,

Write down twenty present passive participles and their feminine and neuter accusative forms.

Translate the following sentences into English and convert them into yad-tad constructions:

‡•ß. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§≠‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•®. ‡§ó‡§ú‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§É ‡§∂‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•©. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•™. ‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡•´. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§∂‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•¨. ‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á ‡§ö ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§Ø‡§É ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•≠. ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§® ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡•Æ. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•Ø. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∂‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¶. ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•®. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§® ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©. ‡§≠; ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡•Å ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•™. ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∏‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•´. ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§É ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§

Translate the following sentences into English and convert them into present participle constructions:

‡•ß. ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§≤‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§‡•§ ‡•®. ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡§É ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•©. ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•™. ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∏‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•´. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§∏‡•á, ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡•¨. ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•≠. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§µ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•Æ. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ú‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ú‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∂‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•Ø. ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•à‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡•à‡§É ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä

‡§Ö‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¶. ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§É ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á ‡§è‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§§‡•à‡§É ‡§ú‡§®‡•à‡§É ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§¶‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§¶‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•®. ‡§®‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§µ‡•á‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§® ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§π‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•™. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§É ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

Translate the following into Sanskrit:

06

  1. I like the boy who is speaking (‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑) to that girl. 2. The girl, looking at (‡§à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑) the mother, ran away. 3. The people praised the teacher who was praising (‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç) God.

The burden being carried by the servants was heavy. The mother, rejoicing (15) having seen her son, came out of the house. The king likes the lotuses growing qy) in the lake. We saw the elephants dying on the mountain. The wife, being abused by her husband, told him: “Leave this house.” The woman, being thought about by me, does not at all

think of me. 10. The flowers, being thrown in the water of the river by

the girl, were brought out of the water by the boy.

Write any five Sanskrit sentences of your own.

174

22

Past (imperfect) participles

The past (imperfect) participles are in general threefold:

a) Past Passive Participles (affix -ta) (400) b) Past Active Participles (affix -tavat! -ta for some

verbs) (pdf) c) Past Intransitive Passive Participles (affix -ta) (UTC) Past passive participles cffet

All verbs, except the intransitive verbs, can have their past passive participles formed with the affix -ta. Though in most of the forms one does find -ta, in several forms it is replaced by the allomorphs na, ta, -dha, dha, etc. For some verbs, the affix -ta becomes -ita obligatorally, for some it becomes -ita optionally, while for others it never takes the augment i. Since these and other changes are for the most part difficult to gener alize, the best way is to study the listed forms and then assimi late them by using them in sentences. Examples:

“that which was eaten”

‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§- < ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø “that which was gone to”

71- < Tula “that which was spoken”

‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§- < ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§§‡•á “that which was remembered”

A

The past passive participle can replace past passive forms in subordinate and main clauses. A past passive participle functions like an adjective of the object of the passive verb, and it follows the gender, number and case of the word for the object. In masculine and neuter, the past passive participles are declined like masculine and neuter nouns in a. In feminine, a feminine marker affix ƒÅ is added to the basic stem, and the feminine stem

is declined like a feminine noun in √£. For example, afga: (m), alga (n), alcat (f).

175

Examples: la 274 GIA HERI “The fruit were eaten by RƒÅma.” √Æb HT SIA allait “The fruit were eaten by RƒÅma.” 2a ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§´‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§π‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúI want those fruit

which were eaten by RƒÅma." 26 27 a c

3 Awift I “I want the fruit eaten by RƒÅma.” 3a HIDT 3RRITI “Mother was remembered by me.” 3b 14 HIT WAT I “Mother was remembered by me.” 4a ret 4 ud 31- I “All (people) cursed the

man who was cursed by (his) wife.” 4b 4RUT AR T 31 “All (people) cursed the man

cursed by his wife.” Past intransitive passive (Ho) participles

For all intransitive verbs, and transitive verbs used without objects, one can have the past intransitive passive participles. The semantic and syntactic focus of these participles is the action itself and not the agent or the object. The participle is formed exactly like the past passive participle, but is used always in neuter singular. These participles are not as frequent as the passive or active past participles.

Examples: la THU PRICI lb THU TH·ªä L. 2a $d: 31 ≈Ωb a: Tal –ó–∞ ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§ ‡•§ ≈Ωb 21 ERDHI

“Going was done by RƒÅma.” “Going was done by RƒÅma.” “Speaking was done by the gods.” “Speaking was done by the gods.” “Laughing was done by me.” “Laughing was done by me.” “Remembering was done by that woman.” ‚ÄúRemembering was done by that woman."

46

YTTRI 4541

Past active cadit participles

For all verbs, the past active participles can be formed by adding the affix -vat to a past passive participle with the affix

176

-ta. Or one might say that the past active participle affix is -tavat. These participles can replace past active verbs occurring in the main or subordinate clauses. They agree in gender, number and case with the agent of the active verb.

Examples:

“he who ate” “he who went” “he who spoke” “he who remembered”

‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç Masculine

D

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç

Nom Acc Inst

Dat Abl Gen Loc Voc

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø Acc

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä

‡§ó‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ Voc

‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø The rest of the forms are like the

masculine forms. In feminine, ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§- takes the feminine marker affixi and hence the feminine stem is ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä. This is declined like ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä. Examples: 1a ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‚ÄúRama went home." 1b ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‚ÄúRama went home.‚Äù 2a ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡§´‡§≤‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‚ÄúI saw the man who ate the fruit." 2b ‡§´‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ “I saw the man who ate the fruit.”

177

3a

man

3b

mar

‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‚ÄúThe king spoke to the man who

remembered (his) mother." ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‚ÄúThe king spoke to the man who

remembered his mother." 7374196 I “She said.” THIRAI “She said.”

4a 4

Past active participles of) in -ta

In the case of verbs which are either inherently intransitive or are used intransitively, verbs of movement and certain other verbs like sthƒÅ, vas, jan, ruh, etc. (which may be contextually transitive, e.g. 314+EYT"to occupy"), the past active participle may be formed with the affix -ta. This looks very much like the past passive participle, but is in syntactic agreement with the agent.

Examples 1 14: " I 14: “a: 1 “RƒÅma went.” 2 flat fardati a Fiat ‚ÄúSƒ´tƒÅ stood.‚Äù 3 d 394 T: 1 a 3a : #: 1 “He lived in the forest.” 4 a: Edard: 1 dat: Erat: “The gods laughed.” 5 A facacit i Freydal “The woman fell.” 6 44 dan 1 944 3f8a: ‚ÄúHe lived in the

village.”

Aspectual versus Tense marking usage of past participles:

In general, one may say that the past participle, when used to replace the finite verb of a main clause conveys the sense of past tense. Thus, the following pairs of sentences are identical in meaning:

“RƒÅma ate the fruit.”

“RƒÅma ate the fruit.” The FIA I “The fruit were eaten by R.” 27 CIA again I “The fruit were eaten by R.”

178

However, the past participle, when used to replace a relative clause verb, or when used in conjunction with another finite verb, conveys the meaning of completion, rather than past tense. In these usages, the past participle conveys a perfect tense. Consider the following sentences:

Present Perfect ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø (or rather ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø) ‡•§ ‚ÄúRama is gone." Past Perfect ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‚ÄúRama was gone." Future Perfect ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡§ó‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‚ÄúRama will be gone."

In such constructions, the tense is conveyed by the finite verb, while the past participle conveys the sense that one action is already complete by the time the other action comes about.

Past participles

Note: These forms are generated according to the rules of Sanskrit, but in actual usage some forms will be found to be quite common, while others are rarely seen. This is especially the case with a large number of a participles. Occasionally, we notice that certain participles are more common in conjunction with prepositions, rather than by themselves. Thus, while from ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§¶‡§§‡§ø is rare, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§£, ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§® etc. are common.

Past Passive & Intrans. Passive ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§

Past Active

in ‡§§

‡§à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü

‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡§ø‡§§

Past Active

‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§à‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

‡§ï‡•É‡§∑

‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§

‡§ó‡§§

‡§ó‡§æ‡§π

‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§

‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§§

‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§

‡§ú‡§®‡•ç

‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§ó‡§£‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ó‡§§ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢, ‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ò‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø‡§§, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§§ ‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§§‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¶‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§

‡§ú‡§æ‡§§

‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç

‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§

‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç

‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç

‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¢‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ò‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§ ‡§¶‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ß‡•Å‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§†‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§

‡§≠‡§§ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§ ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§

‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§

‡§ä‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç (2P) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç (4A) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç (6P) ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü

‡§∞‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§â‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§â‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ä‡§¢‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

‡§∂‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§

‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò

‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®

‡§∏‡§¶

‡§∏‡•É‡§§

‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§

‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§

‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü

BEEEEne

‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§ ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡§§

‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§§

Exercises

Translate the following into English:

‡•ß. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•®. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ ‡•§ ‡•©. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡•ã ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•™. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•´. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•å ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§π ‡§∏‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡•§ ‡•¨. ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Å ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡•§ ‡•≠. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç? ‡•Æ. ‡§ú‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•å ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•å ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡•§ ‡•Ø. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¶. ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§É ‡§ï‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•®. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§Ø ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç (bad poem) ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡•á ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§É ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç? ‡•ß‡•™. ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•´. ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡•§

NAV

Rewrite the story in Lesson 9, Exercise 1, after converting its sentences into past participle constructions wherever possible.

182Convert all the past tense forms in the story of the mustard seed in Lesson 11 to past participles and list the original forms along with the participial forms appropriate in the context.

Translate into Sanskrit using past participles:

i asti

o

  1. RƒÅma went to LankƒÅ (f.) to defeat RƒÅvana.

The king saw the servant and laughed. The servant, fallen on the ground, said to the king. The crows, seated on the tree, ate fruits. RƒÅma’s sister spoke to her mother-in-law.

The poem written by you was seen by me. 7. The swan who stood on the bank of the lake flew up

(3¬¢+/4). 8. God protected the people who worshipped him.

The jackals ate the flesh of the dead elephants. The minds of good-hearted people rejoiced seeing the

moon risen (3G+/14) in the sky. 11. The mother, who reached heaven, saw her son seated at

the court of Indra. The priest, struck by the mendicant, was seen by the

doctor. 13. The king gave wealth to the poet who wrote a poem to

praise him. 14. The mendicants, saluted by the king, showed him the path

of moral conduct (‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø f.). 15. The poems of the dead poet were burned with his body.

Write any five Sanskrit sentences of your own.

183

23

P

D

P

Demonstrative pronouns ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‚Äúthis" and ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç “that”

Of these two pronouns, is the more common pronoun. Certain forms of 3TGT, though not all, are also frequent. Accord ing to the Sanskrit tradition, ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç refers to things nearby, ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç refers to things very near, ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§∏ refers to distant things and ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç refers to things which are remote. These meanings are relative.

‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§Ö‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç

Masculine

Masculine D ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§Æ‡•ã

‡§Ö‡§∏‡•å ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§ ‡§á‡§Æ‡•å/ ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç/

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç ‡§è‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§®‡•å ‡§è‡§®‡§æ‡§® I ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§®/ ‡§Ü‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§≠‡§ø‡§É

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§è‡§®‡•á‡§® D ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§Ü‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Ab ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É G ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§ ‡§è‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§è‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É L ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É/ ‡§è‡§∑‡•Å

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∑‡•Å ‡§è‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É

‡§á‡§Æ‡•á

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç

Feminine

Feminine ‡§á‡§Æ‡•á ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É

‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§É‡•§

‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ã

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç

__ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§É

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§É

‡§è‡§®‡•á

‡§Ü‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§≠‡§ø‡§É

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ

N ‡§á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç Ac ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§

‡§è‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç I ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§

‡§è‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ D ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à Ab ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É G ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≠‡§ø‡§É

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§Ü‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ü‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ü‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Ü‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§è‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É ‡§Ö‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Å ‡§è‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É

FREE

L ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∑‡•Å

Neuter

Neuter N ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§Æ‡•á ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø Ac ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§Æ‡•á‡•§ ‡§á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø/

‡§è‡§®‡•á ‡§è‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ø The rest like the Masc.

‡§Ö‡§¶‡§É

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø

‡§è‡§®‡§§‡•ç

The rest like the Masc.

Dual forms of nouns and verbs which end in , J and T, as explained before, do not undergo any sandhi operations. The same holds true of the plural form ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä. For instance, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø cannot be transformed into *‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø . As for the use of the pronouns ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç, they are very similar to ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç etc. The

optional forms of ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç such as ‡§è‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§è‡§®‡•å are used in secondary . or subsequent references to entities.

A1) ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§

A2) ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ . This man / this one will go." B1) ‡§á‡§Æ‡•á ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§É (bees) ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ B2) ‡§á‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•Å ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

“These bees / these ones drink honey.” C1) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ C2) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§

“I see the wealth of that woman / that one.” D1) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ D2) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§

“Those lotuses / those ones appeal to her.” E1) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡•á‡§£ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§É ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ E2) ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§

‚ÄúThis servant / this one is beaten by that king / that one."

Nouns with two stems

Certain nouns (and adjectives) ending in consonants show two stems in their paradigms, the strong stem before some terminations and the weak stem before other terminations. In a masculine paradigm, the strong stem appears in Nom. (S, D, P), Acc. (S, D) and Voc. (S, D, P); in a neuter paradigm, the strong stem appears in Nom. (P), Acc. (P) and Voc. (P). As usual, these three forms are identical in a neuter paradigm. following noun-types with two stems:

a

we

186

These

Past active participles ending with the affix -‡§§‡§µ‡§§‡•ç. have been discussed in the preceeding lesson.

B.

Present and future active participles such as ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç. These are discussed in Lesson 19. We may note a few differences here. The masc. nom. singular is ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç, rather than ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç. The neuter nom. and acc.dual forms for the conjugations 1, 4, 10, causatives, desideratives and denominative verbs are strong forms. e.g. ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä . For the 6th conjugation, for the 2nd conjugation verbs ending in 317, and all future active participles, the neuter nom. and acc. dual forms are optionally strong, e.g., ‡§§‡•Å‡§¶‡§§‡•Ä/‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä, ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä/ ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä. Present active participles from other verbs have weak forms in their neuter nom. and acc. dual, e.g. ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä. Neuter plurals for verbs in the 3rd conjugation and a few other participles such as ‡§ú‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç are optionally strong, e.g., ‡§¶‡§¶‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§ø. With all these exceptions, it is good to keep in mind that these neuter forms are extremely rare in the actual

usage.

Nouns ending in the possessive affixes -‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç and -‡§µ‡§§, e.g. ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç. The paradigms of these nouns are exactly identical with those of the old participles. . The feminine stem is formed by adding -‡§à, e.g., ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç > ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä.

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç (m)

‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç (m)

D

P

D

DP N ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§É ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Ab ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç L

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ã‡§É

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å

‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É

‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§ø

187

D. Adjectives of quantity ending in the affixes -‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç and -‡§µ‡§§‡•ç,

e.g., ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç, ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç. These paradigms are similar to those of nouns in A and B. The feminine is formed by adding -‡§à, e.g., ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä.

‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‚Äúthis much‚Äù or ‚Äúthis many" Masculine

Neuter s DP

s DP N ‡§á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç __ ‡§á‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§á‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø Ac ‡§á‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç __ ‡§á‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø I ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§á‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É

Like the masculine D ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§á‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Like the masculine Ab ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡§É ‡§á‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§á‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Like the masculine G ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡§É

‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç

Like the masculine - ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å

Like the masculine v ‡§á‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§á‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§á‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø

Vocabulary

‚Ä¢ ‡§á‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç

‚Ä¢ ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç (mfn) that

‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç (mfn) this . ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞ (m) bee

‚Ä¢ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç Lord, respected

‚Ä¢ ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç intelligent

‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç intelligent

‚Ä¢ ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡•ç strong, powerful

‚Ä¢ ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç rich

‚Ä¢ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç learned

‚Ä¢ ‡§Ö‡§™+‡§π (‡§π‡§∞‡§§‡§ø, 1P) to steal * ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ (m) ocean

‚Ä¢ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø+‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑ (‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§§‡•á, 1A) to reply

long-lived ‡•§ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç

rich ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

Himalaya

‚Ä¢ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç

how much, how many?

this much, this many

‚Ä¢ ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç as much, as many

Palace this much, this many

‚Ä¢ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§ famous

‚Ä¢ ‡§â‡§≠ Pron. both (always dual)

‚Ä¢ ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞ another

Exercises

write the full paradigms of ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ç (m), ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç (0 and ‡§è‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç (n).

188

Translate the following into English:

‡•ß. ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•á‡§® (= Buddha) ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•®. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§§‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•©. ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç - ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ - ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•™. ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡§ø ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡•´. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§®‡§∞‡§æ‡§É ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡•§ ‡•¨. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á? ‡•≠. ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§É‡•§‡•§ ‡•Æ. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú‡•ã ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§£ ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É‡•§ ‡•Ø. ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡•§ ‡•ß‡•¶. ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡•á ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•ß. ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ

‡§π‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡§µ‡§¶‡§™‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§â‡§≠‡•å ‡§§‡•å ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§π‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç ‡§§‡§µ ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç - ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§§‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•©. ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ö‡§® ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç - ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞

‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§§ - ‡§π‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∏‡§ø? ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç, ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§¨‡§≤‡§Ç, ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç, ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç

‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§æ? ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡•ß‡•™. ‡§ï‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç - ‡§π‡•á ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞, ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ ‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

‡§§‡§¶‡§æ ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ω‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§®‡§µ‡§§‡§É ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§Æ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§∞‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§¶‡§§‡§ø - ‡§π‡•á ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§®‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•á, ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Å ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

Translate from English into Sanskrit:

How much gold does that rich man have? Nowhere else is there so much wind as there is on the Himalaya mountain. This strong man did not think that his intelligent enemy was able to defeat him.

189

wo

0

That rich woman does not have as many horses as I have. I pray to the Lord, ‚ÄúLet me be long-lived and rich." The Buddha instructed the people, saying: “You must abandon as many desires as you have.” Going along the road towards my village, I saw that famous man who lived in the king’s palace. A rich man desires gold as much as a bee desires honey. How much knowledge do you desire? How much strength do you desire? In that house which belongs to the learned men are many books.

The intelligent men, praising the qualities of the Lord, say: “Knowledge found only in books leads to adversity and misery. However, knowledge found through meditation on the Lord leads to great happiness.”

Write any five Sanskrit sentences of your own.

24

More nouns in two stems

A. Honorific Pronoun ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‚Äúyour honor"

This pronoun behaves exactly like the present participle ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡•§ ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å with a few minor differences. The masc. nom, sing. of the pronoun is ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç, while that of the present participle is ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®.

Also, the feminine participle form is ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä , while the feminine pronoun is Hadit. This pronoun is syntactically different from the pronoun ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç requires a 3rd person verb, e.g., ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∏‡§ø, but ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‚ÄúYour honor goes". Often, to show an even higher degree of respect, the plural form can be used to refer to a single person, e.g., ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø . Contextually, this could either refer to many goers, or show a high level of respect for a single goer. In the actual usage of Hac, one finds that authors switch back and forth between 14 and HF referring to the same person, and these switches indicate subtle shifts in the display of respect. In late Sanskrit, the general tendency is to stick to one usage. The words ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•ç are used in the sense of “his honor over here” and “his honor over there”, eg., ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡§É ‡§ú‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§§‡§ø “His honor M. over here drinks water”. Similarly, one finds the feminine forms ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä and ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä, e.g., ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‚ÄúHer honor S. over there wishes to go to the forest". B. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç “great”: strong stem ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, fem. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•Ä

Masculine s. DP

DP N ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø

‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•å ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§É

‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç

‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É Like the Masculine D ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Like the Masculine Ab ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Like the Masculine G ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ã‡§É . ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç Like the Masculine

‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ã‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å

Like the Masculine v ‡§Æ‡§π‡§®‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø

191

C. Words ending the affix -5-!

AS

The affix 5 is used in Sanskrit both as a possessive affix after nouns and as an agentive affix providing agent-nouns, e.g., ‡§¨‡§≤+‡§á‡§®‡•ç > ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‚Äústrong’, ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç+‡§á‡§®‡•ç > ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‚Äúgoer", fem. forms ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä.

S

‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø

Masculine

DP N ‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§É Ac ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•å ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§É I ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§É D ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Ab ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É G ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§É ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç L ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑ v ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ã ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡§É

Neuter DP

‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø Like the Masculine Like the Masculine Like the Masculine Like the Masculine Like the Masculine ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø

Note the forms in which the of the stem is lost before the final affix in the paradigm above (in italics). In these forms, the juncture of the stem and the affix behaves as if it is an external sandhi. This feature is found in several other nominal paradigms. See the paradigm of ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç- below.

Nouns with three stems:

In the above paradigms, we have seen that certain nominals ending in consonants such as ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç show two stems in their paradigms, i.e. one before strong terminations and the other before weak terminations. Here we will look at nominals which show three stems in their paradigms. These may generally be classified into three groups:

a.

perfect

participle

the reduplicated active voice past ending in ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç , nouns ending in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç -, and adjectives of direction ending in 317.

192

With these nominals, the case endings and the strong stems remain the same, while a new category of middle stem is carved out of the weak stem area. In the paradigms given below, the strong stems are shown in italics, and the middle stems are shown in small size letters.

Reduplicated perfect active participle in ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç :

In these paradigms, the strong stem ends in aid, the middle in ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, and the weak in ‡§â‡§∑‡•ç. Here are the paradigms for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç from the root ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç ‚Äúto know" and ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç from the root ‡§ï‡•É ‚Äúto do". The feminine is formed by adding a feminine affix -‡§à, e.g. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä, ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä. This is declined like a standard feminine nominal ending in ‡§à. The masculine and the neuter paradigms are given below. The word Fey is traditionally recognized as a present participle, while ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç, ‡§â‡§™‡•á‡§Ø‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç, ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç, and ‡§ú‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç are considered to be perfect participles.

P

N ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§® Ace ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç I ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ D ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•á Abl ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§É G ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§É L ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø v ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡•ç

“learned person” M

Nt

DP ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É

‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø‡§É ——-like Masc. ——- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ——-like Masc. ——- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ——-like Masc. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ——-like Masc. ——- ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ——-like Masc. —— ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø

193P

‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä

‡•ß

‡§ï‡§∑‡§ø

‡§ö‡§Ø

‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç “one who did” M

Nt DP

D N ‡§ö‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•å ‡§ö‡§ï‡•Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø Acc ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•å ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§§‡•ç

‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø I ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ï‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ï‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É

D ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•á ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Abl ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡§µ‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É G ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å v ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§®‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•å ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø 2. Nouns ending in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç :

With these nouns, the strong stem ends in 3 (the final is dropped in the masculine nominative singular). The middle stem ends in 31, and the weak stem ends in Twith the preceding 34 dropped (sometimes optionally). Observe the following paradigms of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç (m) ‚Äúking", and ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç (n) “name”. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç - strong: = ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•ç, middle: = ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú, weak: = ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç - strong: = ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®, middle: = ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ, weak: = ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ç

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç (m)

‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç (n) PS D N ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä/‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø Acc ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç

‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ

‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä/‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø I ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§É D ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø: Abl ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É G ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§É ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§É . ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø ‡§ú‡§®‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§É ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Å ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§ø/‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•Å v ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•å ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§É ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ/‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä/‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç (I) “border”, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•ç (m) “head”, and ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç (m) ‚Äúsoul’, decline like ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç (n) “path” and ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç (n) “armor” decline like ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç. Only ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç and ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡•ç have the contraction in the weak forms, i.e. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡•ç and ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§®. ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç, ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç, and ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç do not have contracted weak forms. Thus, their ins. sg. forms are ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ, ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ, and ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ.

P

‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É

‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç

194

Adjectives of direction ending in ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç -

For these nominals, the strong stem ends in 31‚Ç¨, the middle stem ends in 374. The weak stem ends in a when 3% in the stem is preceded by ‡§Ø‡•ç, e.g. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç, and it ends in ‡§ä‡§ö‡•ç when ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç in the stem is preceded by , e.g. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç.

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç - ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç -

strong: = ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö, strong: = ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö,

middle: = ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö, __weak: = ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö middle: = ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç, weak: = ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç “backward, westward”

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï

S N ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç Ace ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç I ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ D ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•á Abl ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§É G ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§É L ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ø v ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡•å ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç

D ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ã‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç ‚Äúpervading

P N ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø Acc ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡§É‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø I ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø:

‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Abl ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É G ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ö‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç . ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ö‡•ã‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å v ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡•å ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§É ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø

P

195

Exceptions:

_The weak stem for the word ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç is ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç. The words ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç and ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç have only two stems. The strong stems are ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö and ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ö, and the weak stems are ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç and ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç.

Feminine forms for the above nominals:

For all the three types of nouns (with three stems) given above, the feminine stems are formed by simply adding

their weak stem. Then the feminine stems are declined like the paradigm of ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä.

Masculine Basic Stem

‡§ö‡§ï‡•É‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ö

Weak Stem ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑

Feminine ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•Ä

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§ö‡•ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç

Degrees of comparison

The comparative degree of adjectives is obtained by adding either the affix -‡§§‡§∞ or -‡§à‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç to the stem. The forms in -‡§§‡§∞ are declined like 31 stems in masculine and neuter, and like 317 stems in feminine. Generally, the comparative forms are accompanied by a word in the ablative to indicate the meaning of “than”. Occasionally, the ablative itself, without the use of an explicit affix of the comparative degree, is found in the usage.

‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡•§ ‚ÄúI am greater than Rama." ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ ‡§è‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ ‡•§ That girl is more

intelligent than this girl." ‡§§‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§§‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡•§ ‚ÄúThat lotus is smaller than

this lotus."

196

MS

e Common

Generally speaking, while the forms in can be produced from most words, the forms in my are common only for certain adjectives, and their derivation involves many different regular and irregular changes. Some of these are suppletive forms. From the adjective - “small”, we get the masculine and the neuter comparative stem ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç., and the feminine stem ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä. The feminine declension is a straight forward feminine declension in

‡§à. The masculine and the neuter declensions are given below. The strong stem is ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç- and the weak stem is ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç..

Masculine

Neuter s DP SDP N ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•å ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø Ac ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•å ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø

Like the Masculine

Like the Masculine Ab ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É Like the Masculine G ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ã‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç Like the Masculine L ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ã‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å Like the Masculine v ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•å ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø

The superlative degree is obtained by adding either the common affix -‡§§‡§Æ, or the somewhat restricted affix -‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§†, e.g., ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å > ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§Æ and ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†. Since both of these formations end in -‡§Ö, the masculine and the neuter formations are declined like nouns in 31, and the feminine forms are derived by adding -311. Generally speaking, the affixes and 58 require complex changes, as well as suppletion, and must be learned from the table below:

common

near praiseworthy

Positive

‚Ä¢ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï

‚Ä¢ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø
